messageBody:
hyysguyang wrote:
> But the requirement in my top post is :
> Requirement: Reverse the setence 'TDD is a software devolopment
> technology' to 'technology devolopment software a is TDD'.
> Attention please, this is all requirement. No other sentence need to
> be reverse.
>
> In my opinion about the requirement,I think I should not reverse any
> other sentence but
> the 'TDD is a software devolopment technology',so I needn't write so
> many test but the test below
>
> @Test public void testReverse(){
> StringReverser sr=new StringReverser();
> String str = "Tdd is a software devolopment
> technology";
> Assert.assertEquals("technology devolopment software a is
> Tdd",sr.reverse(str));
> }
> after this I refactor to the final code described befoe.Maybe I make
> a large jump.
>
> Okay,Now I know what mistake that I have made.The mistake is my
> misunderstand the requirement,
> In fact I have got a dead end.

Greetings Yang Gu,

Hah! Fool me once. :-)

I think your post is a good example of the importance of
paying attention and asking questions. I certainly failed that
test in this case! I remember a test I took in grade school:

1. read all instructions before proceeding
2. write down the names of the planets
3. etc.
...
25. ignore all preceding steps

I hadn't even noticed that a number of kids had put their pencil
down in the first 20 seconds. Yeah, sure, read instructions.

The initial solution you provided presents more than a simple
refactoring. It's a generalization, one that your requirement
doesn't demand. I wouldn't have bothered with the refactoring
in that case--the unnecessary logic introduces unnecessary risk
(which is particularly higher given the absence of more
comprehensive tests).

Best regards,
Jeff L.
